explanation: To determine whether OS_SocketAccept_Impl uses any compiler language extensions you must inspect any macros, typedefs, constants and called APIs that can hide extensions. Provide: (1) OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_impl_filehandle_table — the macro expansion may use GCC/clang statement-expressions, typeof, __extension__, inline asm, or other extensions; (2) OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — the struct definition may contain bitfields, unnamed members, compiler-specific attributes or extension types; (3) OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS — macro could use compiler-specific constructs or attributes; (4) OS_SockAddr_t — the typedef/struct may use flexible array members, attributes, or other extensions and defines the ActualLength and AddrData layout used here; (5) OS_object_token_t — its typedef/representation may use compiler extensions (e.g., packed/transparent unions); (6) OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE — constant definition might be created with extension syntax or non-standard types; (7) OS_SelectSingle_Impl — its declaration/definition might use inline, naked, or other extension keywords affecting the call; (8) OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT, OS_ERROR — these macros/constants may be defined using extension constructs; (9) socklen_t, accept, struct sockaddr — these platform/POSIX symbols determine whether any nonstandard typedefs or prototypes (e.g., using extension types) are in use. Inspecting these symbols lets the analyzer see whether any language/compiler extensions are present (hidden inside macros, typedefs, attributes, or function declarations) which would violate the MISRA rule.
